Award.AwardTitle: CI-P: Shared Open-Source Tools in Support of Multimedia Systems Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Community Infrastructure-Planning (CI-P) project will focus on planning for a community infrastructure project to develop a multimedia toolkit to help catalyze multimedia systems and networking research. The proposed multimedia toolkit will solve a number of problems faced by the multimedia systems community. By providing a toolkit that is focused more on readability, modularity, and ease of modification, we expect that such a toolkit will help to decrease the time it takes to train new graduate students to become multimedia researchers and allow them to more readily create new technology rather than making modifications to highly-optimized, brittle software tools that are used today.

Early multimedia toolkits such as the Berkeley MPEG-1 tools or Open Mash tools from the 1990s helped to catalyze research in the multimedia community by providing a set of tools that made it relatively easy to experimentally deploy, test, and measure multimedia systems. The succession of video compression standards like H.264 / MPEG-4 and H.265 / HEVC, however, has had a negative impact on the ability to do experimental video systems and networking projects as well as the ability to use recent standards in an educational setting due to the high complexity of the compression tools. This project will address this through a multimedia toolkit with the following goals:
- Significantly reduce training time to bring students up to speed on the latest video compression and decompression tools,
- Enable more rapid modifications to video coding algorithms and provide the ability to more quickly build new multimedia systems, and
- Provide several profiles for the research community to use so that results across different research projects can be more readily compared.

The planning phase of this open source tool in support of multimedia systems includes: (i) surveying and gathering the needs of the research community with respect to their research and the education of their students, (ii) designing the overall architecture, and (iii) soliciting further feedback from the community with regards to the toolkit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This planning grant focused on preparing a proposal for the creation of a community-based toolkit to allow for the research and education using modern video compression formats. Due to the increasing complexity of video compression formats and computer-vision based algorithms, it has become increasingly more difficult for multimedia systems graduate researchers to make effective contributions without spending a significant amount of time learning video compression formats, particularly for those multimedia systems that are adaptive to underlying resources (e.g., computing cycles, networking bandwidth).

There were a number of outcomes of the planning grant:

o) We convened two workshops with leaders in the multimedia systems community to discuss the components of the toolkit, the requirements that would be needed for a diversity of multimedia systems research, and to discuss the set of technologies and toolkits they currently use.  The first workshop discussed the overview of our planning grant project and the community’s initial thought on components.  At the second workshop, we described the work that we had done and sought further feedback on the proof of concepts we had implemented. Through these workshops, we identified being able to shuttle data in and out of compressed video formats and integrating real-time into computer vision algorithms as necessary components of the proposed community research infrastructure

o) In order to enable the envisioned extensible toolkit, a necessary component was the ability to shuttle data in and out of modern video compression formats in a pipelined fashion. This is in contrast to the standard approach of completely decoding a video into an intermediate format, performing a multimedia processing function on all data, and then compressing back into a video format.  For example, the standard OpenCV file interface requires a complete file rather than a stream of multimedia data.  To this end, we created a proof-of-concept toolkit that allows users to seamlessly combine video compression / decompression, image processing, and computer vision.  We leveraged the ffmpeg toolkit, the Pbmplus image processing libraries, and the OpenCV libraries, respectively.  Our work concentrated on (i) creating an intermediate format that was flexible enough to allow users to specify a variety of envisioned tasks, and (ii) creating wrappers around the various toolkits to be able to link them together.  Our proof-of-concept defined a BSON (Binary JavaScript Object Notation) format to allow users to tag, control, and access the information being generated by the various toolkits. We also created a wrapper and dispatching mechanism to open up the interfaces within the toolkits to work with the BSON format we created.

o) One of the key needs identified by the multimedia systems research community was integrating computer vision algorithms into the toolkit. Because content-based processing is primarily driven by the application-level knowledge, mechanisms are needed to expose low-level details from the computer vision processing (e.g., saliency) to the application or multimedia system needing to adapt processing to underlying resources.We have defined and created a proof-of-concept of a new OpenCV interface for video capture that allows vision algorithms to provide feedback to the media capture and streaming infrastructure saliency information to inform compression and streaming decisions. The interface designed has three principle goals. The interface should be generic, allowing vision algorithms to express saliency both spatially and temporally in the most general terms possible, avoid assumptions about both the compression and streaming techniques used behind the interface as well as the vision algorithm in front of the interface. The interface should as much as possible separate the concerns of compression control from rate control in order to allow independent configuration of these mechanisms if desired. While integration of source and channel control are foundational principles in multimedia systems, we understand that vision researchers may find it challenging to negotiate these tradeoffs at first. The current OpenCV interfaces for video do very little to expose compression and streaming latency. At the very least, we believe the new interface should provide the ability to track the delay associated with compression control and rate control of a video source.
